item.title: How to make a contour map
item.description:
How to Make a Contour Map

 

Now that the difference between DEM and SRTM (and other data sources) is clearer, the goal of this guide is to create a contour map using SRTM data we got through Topodata.

 

What is a Contour Map?

This type of map uses lines (called contour lines) that connect points of the same altitude on the Earth’s surface. Using this kind of map, we can get a much better feel for a region’s terrain, allowing for topographic studies, planning for agriculture, and other area-specific analyses.

item.title: SRTM, DEM, what are those?
item.description:
SRTM, DEM, and Others… What Do They Even Mean, and What’s the Difference?

 

Maybe when you first had to start dealing with altitude data, you heard these terms thrown around and wondered what they meant or if they were the same thing.

First off, it’s good to know that we can describe the Earth’s terrain—its shape and structure—using something called geomorphometric data. A classic example of this is the contour maps we can create for a specific area.
